content: so sometime in the second half of 2023 I'd like to update roc-lang.org again
to reflect all the progress we've made!

so far the goals of the website have been:

  • have the level of polish of the website reflect the level of polish of the language itself, as a way to give you a sense of what you're getting into (e.g. don't have the website look super polished and then you try out the language and it's all WIPs and TODOs)
  • don't "pitch" the language (because it's not far enough along for that yet)
  • rather, offer some basic information about the language and provide links to learn more, so people can make informed decisions about investing time into it.

so at a high level, I think a good goal for the next iteration of the website would be "looks more like a typical programming language website" (e.g. it's actually styled, unlike today's which is explicitly unstyled) but still isn't a "pitch" website. It's not trying to sell you on how awesome Roc is; rather, it talks about the goals and current progress toward those goals
so the content would be similar to today, but it would look more like a normal language website - e.g. it would have a real layout, navigational links (like the tutorial does across the top), etc.
and then the biggest change I'd like to make is to incorporate the web repl into the front page, so you can try out the language right away

specifically I like the idea of having a little code snippet right there, but have it be something you can interact with right away if you focus into the input box right below it (I have some ideas on how this could look and work)
so if anyone is interested in working on this, lmk! I know @Georges Boris has expressed interest, but maybe others are interested in collaborating on it too!

I want to give an update on progress with the 2023 website for @Georges Boris @Éber Freitas Dias and anyone else who is interested in contributing. PRs most welcome :smile:

We have made a start on the basic structure for the new site which for now is sitting at www/wip_new_website on main, and includes a local build script using roc run build.roc. It is generated using the static-site-gen platform which gives us Roc code syntax highlighting and enables most of the content to be written in markdown.

Ideally we will update the site prior to Roctoberfest, as this supports that activity and in preparation for 2023 Advent of Code.

The new site has the following structure;

  • index home page, minimal content with links to other pages
    • design goals describe the design and user requirements for the language and ecosystem design
  • tutorial to guide people new to Roc through the basics
  • install quick start for getting and using Roc
  • examples a collection of code which show Roc in action
  • community information about the community and contributing
  • sponsor information about how to sponsor Roc
  • docs links to the documentation and guides

The initial focus has been to try and scope out what should be included. For now this basically just pages and headings which loosly define structure, and are supported by dot points or comments to capture ideas. Richard provided input here so we have a reasonable starting point.

There is a lot of things that need work. For example there has been almost no work on styling or content. It is still very much a work in progress and all contributions welcome.

Some ideas for things that would be hlepful;

  • styles and layout for the pages to look good
  • integrate the web REPL for the front page
  • write a short language reference (move some things out of tutorial e.g. de-sugaring table, keywords)
  • write a brief explanation of platform/application abstraction versus libraries as common in most other languages
  • write a brief summary of the current state of using Roc for Tools & Scripts, Web, Networking & Servers, Graphical, Scientific, Embedded etc
Also you can visit the WIP site sitting on main at https://www.roc-lang.org/wip

• In the opportunistic mutation section: consider moving the discussion of all the cases regarding opportunistic mutation to the "Roc is fast" document. Reading it, it wasn't clear to me where the point was going until the discussion that values are semantically immutable, which feels like the crux of what this section is about. A smaller sentence like "Values are immutable, but will be optimistically mutated if they are known to be unique, either at compile-time or run-time. And we try very hard to find the unique ones at compile time; see [fast] for more details" may be enough. Loved the rest of the section
  • No reassignment or shadowing:
    • regarding the last paragraph about performance benefits of early-return CF: I think the greater benefit in general is that early-return can be more idiomatic/easier to read in imperative code, and it is pretty common in imperative styles. It might be worth talking about that, to me it seems more pertinent than concerns regarding performance
  • Managed effects over side effects - some nitpicks
    • "runtime effect system outside the program istelf": s/istelf/itself, but also consider saying "runtime effect interpreter" or "runtime effect evaluator" instead. Effect systems are typically semantic on a program, and it's not the case that we are performing e.g. effect-checking at runtime. obviously a nitpick, noting as a hedge. It may also be worth mentioning that right now the model of side effects is monadic and does not have the semantics of typical (algebraic) effects, but there is a plan to change that.
    • "anything that can be evaluated at compile time is evaluated then. This saves work at runtime, and is easy to opt out of: if you want evaluation to happen at runtime, you can instead wrap the logic in a function and call that as needed. In the design, infinite loops are permitted.": if wrapping an evaluation behind a function removes it from eligibility for CE, how can there be infinite loops?
